newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Hun Sen sees majority from royalist split.
newsitem.headline: Hun Sen sees majority from royalist split.

text.p: Cambodian strongman Hun Sen said on Friday that dissident royalists had given him an outright majority in parliament.
Hun Sen is second prime minister in an awkward partnership set up after a U.N.-managed election in 1993 that was intended to make political peace after more than two decades of civil war.
He shares Cambodia's divided government power with First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who now faces a split in his FUNCINPEC royalist party.

Hun Sen, whose Cambodian People's Party and allies control 56 votes in the 120-seat national assembly, told reporters on Saturday that 12 of FUNCINPEC's 58 members of parliament had now split with Ranariddh.

He pledged to oppose any attempt to remove the dissidents from government and political posts, offering them political backing, financial assistance and protection. "They (Ranariddh's supporters) should not forget we (the CPP) have 51 seats in the national assembly," he said.

Hun Sen denied Ranariddh's charges he had engineered the rift but said his party had the right to agree with the prince's critics. "It is not a coup d'etat, it's just a split in a party in which the other side has received the support of CPP," he said
He said the that CPP could now count on a parliamentary majority but did not want to remove Prince Ranariddh as co-premier.

A CPP statement gave the names of only 11 defecting royalist MPs, including Ung Phan, a minister of state who announced the split on Tuesday by rejecting Ranariddh's leadership and blaming him for the dismal coalition relations.

The dissident royalists could give the CPP the votes it needs to pass legislation but it would still be short of the two-thirds majority needed to amend the constitution, dismiss senior government officials and lift the immunity of MPs.
The next session of parliament was due to open on Monday but has been postponed .
Hun Sen said the differences between the parties should not disturb the work of government and "I don't believe this tension could lead to bloodshed."
The dissidents plan to hold a congress soon to challenge Ranariddh's leadership. The FUNCINPEC steering committee on Friday expelled Ung Phan and four party officials.
